path.title: Identity
* Open system * User sovereign identity * Memorable identifiers * Indexible registry * Semantic data
Problems of: data; privacy; trust (technical vs. social)
Privacy: Never allow raw data to leave repository! Data encrypted at all times! Always return aggregate answers!

polygon.title: * quality * security * freedom/independence * source * privacy * binding to real world * attributes * provenance/trust * availability/persistance * auditability

path.title: People: True identity persistence: bundles of attributes (see Ship of Theseus)
Orgs
Devices
Ideas
* user sovereign * decentralized * distributed * proof of ownership
Identity for everyone * biometric attestation * number, size, connections * utilization: payments; mutual assets; services

Overall architecture of blockchain identity services * what belongs/doesn't * where and how stored * redundancy * zone files and pointers * hardware * storage of keys * multiple IDs * privacy and data limitation * as little as possible should be stored in blockchain (common, minimal core)
* architecture standard * roles * DNS zone files
Identity anchored and enabled by the blockchain

Verifiable claims data models * privacy ** selective disclosure ** editing/storage * work with current legal framework * blockchain not a panacea * economic incentives * lifetime-right to be forgotten
Join the Verifiable Claims Task Force!
Many opportunities! Truly universal: An open standard on an open platform

Efficient thin-client verification of identity * non-membership proof problem ** index data and commit ** linear commitment * freshness problem ** proof of work ** query for hash chains ** classical BFT system ** Oracle system ** out-of-band communication
Too much identity! * least possible! * spectrum: nothing; ephemeral; persistent; linked persistent to biological ID / legal ID (only if needed) * use attribution or ephemeral ID when possible

Hyperledger, IBM Membership, Services architecture * centralized and decentralized services * long-term and short-term ID pieces * private and permissioned ledgers ** long-lived/authorization certs ** transactional certs, reduce/prevent corrolation ** specificity may go down over time ** rely on third-party vendors

Blockchain standards in healthcare * connection to existing legal structures / regulation requirements * drive cost of ownership to edges * aggregational issue and transactional issue * safeguard integrity * leave data at point of origin * standards: ** blockchain and self-sovereign ID ** authorization ** digital postmark * tech ** self-sovereign mobile ** self-sovereign server ** reputation
dpict. graphical scribing and facilitation
